During the discussions on the proposal for a common regulatory framework for electronic communications networks and services (COM(2008)0580 – C6-0333/2008 – COD 2008/0187), voters in my constituency (two regions on the Polish-German border) drew my attention to the issue of 'accidental roaming'. This is my new sentence. I am the speaker adding a line.


Accidental roaming involves involuntary connection to a foreign network when using one's mobile telephone in a border region. Without crossing the border, inhabitants of such regions can pick up the signal broadcast by a mobile phone operator in the neighbouring country and, as a result, pay much higher call, text and data-transmission charges.


Is the Commission aware of this problem? What steps will be taken, or have already been taken, to put an end to this major inconvenience for mobile phone users in border areas?
What measures will the Council take in order to support the cessation of the sale of arms to Israel in parallel with the actions already taken by the EU to prevent arms reaching Hamas?

However, it may still be feasible to coordinate the actual wording of the question put to voters.

Does the Council not agree that it is highly desirable that the same question should be put to voters in all the EU Member States holding a referendum on the draft constitution?

Will the Council take immediate steps to coordinate the arrangements so as to bring this about?

It is disgraceful - although not to the public, which is blissfully unaware of the situation, because the media are uninterested - that there is currently no Director of Europol, at a time when organised crime is flourishing merrily across our continent, because of a dispute between several Member States about what nationality the new Director should hold.


What is the Commission doing to have an appointment made as soon as possible ?

column5: Administrative reform of the European institutions
column7:
Opinion polls show that citizens see the European institutions as big bureaucratic centres which have a lot of power and are run with a lot of taxpayers’ money. The Prodi Commission began to tackle this problem and Commissioner Kinnock was put in charge of administrative reform of the European institutions.

Has the ‘Kinnock reform’ even begun? Is it in progress? Or has it perhaps already been completed? And if it has been completed, what effects has it had? In your opinion, how many unnecessary administrative obstacles are there in EU regulations? Do you intend to draw up a programme of measures to combat red tape?

  2. Does the Commission consider that a decision to issue bonds will endanger the stability of the eurozone and, if so, how can this danger be offset?
What initiatives is the Kenyan Government putting in place to ensure that the African Union will adopt a united front in the face of the economic crisis?

In 2001 the EU undertook to move progressively towards eliminating all export subsidies on its agricultural products by 2013. However, the EU spent no less than EUR 2.5 billion in export subsidies for the 2006-2007 period. Although the amount may be decreasing, it is still much too high. In an international context characterised by a food crisis and an explosion in agricultural prices, we should be moving much more quickly towards doing away with these subsidies, which have a dumping effect that is intolerable for millions of small producers in the developing countries. Can the Commission say, with the help of statistics and a timetable, exactly what its intentions are on this matter?

The report 'Rethinking the European ICT Agenda', published during the Dutch Presidency, stated that one of the main objectives of the information society was to change the approach from 'access to technology for all' to 'making the necessary information and skills available to all'.

Various surveys have shown that digital skills considerably enhance people's work. In view of the above, what will the Commission do to promote the idea of 'making the necessary knowledge available to all' and increase digital literacy in the European Union?

If UMTS services are to go on developing, the regulatory framework requires that the 900 MHz GSM band be opened up to accommodate them. However, the revision of the GSM Directive 87/372/EEC(1), is very far behind schedule, and Member States are looking to the Commission, the Council, and Parliament to bring clarity to regulation.

Given the critical financial situation in Europe, a quick and responsible way should be found to allocate the band in question and reform the related directive so as to support the mobile communications business. All lawgivers therefore have the task of working towards a Europe-wide solution.

What political and technical measures will the Commission propose in order to avert further delays, which could affect the European electronic communications industry as a whole?

Currently the European Union's 25 members spend about £120 billion a year investing in research and development. Compared with more than £210 billion spent by the United States, this makes EU investment seem minimal. This imbalance is one of the factors contributing to a 'brain drain' of scientific talent from Europe to the US. The Kok report noted that nearly three-quarters of the world's leading IT companies were from the US. What action is the Council prepared to take to improve Europe's knowledge economy?

The European Commissioner for multilingualism — Leonard Orban — is to make an official visit to Italy on 23 March of this year on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Rome treaties. For the first time the sole content of a European Commissioner's portfolio is responsibility for multilingualism — testimony to the increasing importance attached by the EU to acknowledging and encouraging the languages spoken in the Member States. Providing the people of Europe with access to information concerning the EU in their own language is a crucial step towards the full establishment of European citizenship. It is to be hoped that the Commission will honour the commitments it made in its November 2005 Communication (which serves to promote multilingualism within European society, the economic sphere and the Commission itself) and that it will set a good example.


In this connection and in view of the fact that a Commission representative has been appointed in order to tackle the challenges of multilingualism, will the Commission say whether it considers it justifiable that documents intended for all EU citizens (such as the websites and in particular information documents, with the sole exception of official announcements and communications referring to European programmes) should be available in only two or three languages, thereby restricting access by many small local bodies to EU funding?


This is a reference in particular to guides for candidates, to the full texts of invitations to tender (which contain all the information concerning specifications and the criteria for tendering a bid) and to all the various forms needed for the purpose of submitting a proposal. One representative example: the application documents relating to the Lingua programme (which is designed to promote multilingualism) exist only in English, French and German.


Is the Commission intending to remedy this state of affairs (and, if so, how?), which severely hampers full involvement by local bodies in European political life and European initiatives, including the provision of funding?


The author of this question does not regard Reply E-1120/06 (given in May 2006 by Mrs Grybauskaitė on behalf of the Commission) as fully satisfactory, since it does not address the issue of making the documents needed for the purpose of submitting tenders under EU programmes available in all the languages, so as to ensure that all EU citizens have the same opportunities.

The situation of children of EU migrants that are left on their own in the Member State of origin while their parents migrate for work to another Member State has raised considerable concern in some Member States in the last two years. While policies do exist with the aim of improving the living conditions and education of migrant children who moved with their parents working abroad, the phenomenon of children left at home on their own has received little attention. According to the study made by Unicef and Social Alternatives in Romania, almost 350 000 children in 2008 had at least one parent who was working abroad, and nearly 126 000 had both parents working abroad.


The children left behind are at risk of losing care and parental attention.


They are at risk of general lack of care as regards physical and mental health, mental-health related effects such as depression, losing free time to play and develop, lack of school participation and general participation in education and training, malnutrition and child abuse.


Does the Commission plan a study to assess the extent of the situation?


Does the Commission believe that the subject of the children of migrant workers is not only a matter for the government in the sending country but also for the governments of the countries that benefit from the presence of the migrant workers on their labour market?

column5: State aid to non-EU European countries
column7: In this time of economic tumult it is imperative that all nations in Europe are on a level playing field and should not have to be concerned about jobs moving to non-EU countries involved in supplying state aid to ailing firms. If members of the EEC or EFTA such as Switzerland are to reap benefits of increased trade with the EU bloc then it is imperative that they reciprocate by playing by the same rules regarding state aid. The current procedures for remedies of breach of this are slow and cumbersome and offer no protection to those currently losing their jobs. How does the Commission plan to tighten up this area of competition law and ensure there is a fast and effective procedure for dealing with complaints?

column5: Access of European citizens to social security schemes
column7:
It is common for workers in the Öresund region of Sweden to commute across the border between Denmark and Sweden to work. There have been reports in the Swedish media (e.g. Sydsvenskan of 22 November 2008 and 2 January 2009) of Swedish workers involved in accidents who have not received sick pay from their Danish employers or the Danish authorities despite the fact that, under EU rules, the social security scheme of the country in which they work should apply.


What does the Commission intend to do to ensure that European citizens who work in a country other than their own have access to social security schemes?

Efforts to increase attendance at school in the developing world have had considerable success, but the increase in the number of pupils in schools has not been matched by an increase in the number of teachers. In many classrooms in developing countries, the pupil-to-teacher ratio is often 100:1, or even higher. Current International Monetary Fund conditions attached to loans to developing countries place restrictions on public sector spending as a whole, and also impose a ceiling limit for teachers' wages. Millions of school children are not getting the education they need because fiscal rules prevent developing countries from employing enough teachers.


Given that providing children with a decent education is vital to ensuring real, lasting development, will the Council put pressure on the IMF to allow greater fiscal flexibility so that developing countries can provide their children with the teachers they so desperately need?

column5: Infant mortality in the EU Member States
column7:
According to the EURO-PERISTAT findings published in 2008, the rate of infant mortality (death occurring during the first 27 days after birth) in the EU Member States is around 0.2% in Cyprus and Sweden, rising to 0.57% in Latvia. Furthermore, the percentage of underweight babies appears to vary with the geographical location of the country concerned, the number of newborn babies weighing less than 2.5 kilograms being greater in the countries of southern and eastern Europe.


How will the Commission respond to these figures? What steps will it take with a view to eliminating the problem of infant mortality in the Western world of the 21st century, particularly in Europe, which is facing severe demographic problems?

The November 2008 Washington Summit led to an action plan for dealing with the financial and economic crisis. Meanwhile, financial markets and financial institutions remain severely perturbed and under financial distress. The economic situation worldwide is deteriorating further as the malaise spreads to other countries.


In this context, delivering on the Washington action plan is crucial. The April G20 Summit should therefore aim not only to deliver on short-term measures under the action plan, as expected, but must also steer towards an international agreement on the actions to be undertaken in the mid- to longer term, with a detailed timetable for decision and implementation.


It must deliver, in particular, on the following issues:


– short- and long-term steps towards the reduction of global imbalances,


– revision of IMF and World Bank governance,


– improving the role of the IMF in ensuring multilateral surveillance and enhanced resources for the IMF,


– review of the scope of financial regulation worldwide, with special emphasis on institutions, instruments and markets that are currently unregulated, so as to ensure that all systemically important institutions are appropriately regulated,


– revision of governance of the IASB and accounting standards,


– remuneration and incentive models,


– the fight against rising protectionist tendencies.


These and other issues need to be addressed in order to restore the situation on the financial markets and to avoid further negative spillover and damage to the fragile economic situation.


Does the Council share these views? What is the message that the EU will deliver at the G20 Summit in April, in particular on the abovementioned issues? What will the EU’s contribution to the Summit agenda be? How will the Council ensure that the G20 deals successfully with the challenges outlined above? The programme, which is to run from 1 January 2009 until 31 December 2013, has a budget of 55 million euros.


Will the Commission give precise details of the plan of action and the costs of implementing the ‘Safer Internet’ programme in the coming years? Who is eligible to apply to take part in the programme? How and on what activities will funds from the ‘Safer Internet’ programme be spent?

What action is the Council taking to further increase familiarity with, and the popularity of, the European flag and anthem in Member States, and what does the Presidency think of the idea of providing the European anthem, which was first proposed in 1926 by Count Richard Coudenhove-Kalergi, a Czech citizen, with words?

Can the Council ensure:



that a mandatory comprehensive review of the agreement will be undertaken not later than 2013 and at subsequent five-yearly intervals? that this review will analyse the impact and the costs and consequences of implementation of the agreement? that its provisions will be amended and its application adjusted in accordance with the results of this review? that the European Parliament and Cariforum parliaments will be involved in any revision?

In early January the Commission pledged to introduce new measures to support the dairy sector and producers' incomes across Europe in an effort to combat some of the negative effects the current economic crisis is having on the dairy sector. Has the Commission any plans to make similar pledges to support other agricultural sectors and producers who have also been negatively affected by the current economic crisis?

According to the Commission's answer to Written Question P-0189/09 concerning financial support for the media during the worldwide economic crisis, numerous Member States have notified the Commission of State aid to the press, which it has already approved insofar as it was consistent with the provisions of Community law.


Could the Commission say specifically which Member States have already submitted such requests, which of them have been approved, what sums are involved and for which media they are intended? What are the conditions which make this State aid consistent with the provisions of Community law?

Could the Commission indicate if it would be favourably disposed to the idea of creating an annual prize for citizens who have created new ways in which to break down the barriers between the institutions and the people of the EU? Such a scheme could provide an incentive for numerous small- and large-scale schemes that are aimed at promoting information about the work of the EU and MEPs to create a greater flow of information with a localised interest taken into account.

In 2001 the EU undertook to move progressively towards eliminating all export subsidies on its agricultural products by 2013. However, the EU spent no less than EUR 2.5 billion in export subsidies for the 2006-2007 period. Although the amount may be decreasing, it is still much too high. In an international context characterised by a food crisis and an explosion in agricultural prices, we should be moving much more quickly towards doing away with these subsidies, which have a dumping effect that is intolerable for millions of small producers in the developing countries. Can the Commission say, with the help of statistics and a timetable, exactly what its intentions are on this matter?

column5: The Commission's role and participation in the upcoming European elections
column7: Can the Commission inform me of what non-party role it will be playing to increase voter turnout in the European elections?

The Commission has asked the European Parliament to give an opinion on the question whether the EU should sign the Interim Trade Agreement between the EU and Turkmenistan.


1. What are the concrete reasons for which the Council considers it justified to sign the ITA now?


2. Why does the Council want to continue with this process, taking into account the general situation in Turkmenistan?


3. What comments does the Council have to make on the various reports by NGOs and people living in Turkmenistan on the situation in the country?


4. What concrete improvements will the ITA make to the relationship between the EU and Turkmenistan?


5. What concrete improvements may the ITA make to the situation in Turkmenistan, especially concerning human rights and democracy?

ccording to the renowned British Economic Research Council, most European agencies are duplicating the work of the relevant national agencies and moreover are forcing private entities out of the market. The ERC therefore advocates that some of these agencies, for example the Community Plant Variety Office, be abolished. Similar criticisms have also been expressed, for example, concerning the Fundamental Rights Agency, in this case by the Council of Europe.


What is the Commission's response to these authoritative criticisms? Does the Commission intend to set up additional agencies in future?

column5: Patent application and maintenance costs in Europe
column7: Between 2000 and 2006 the EU's world share of gross domestic expenditure in Research and Development (GERD) decreased by 7.6% and its share in patent applications declined by 14.2%, or nearly twice as much. The developed Asian Economies the share of patent applications increased over the same period by 53%. A main contributory factor to this disparity is the cost of applying for and maintaining a patent in the EU, which is currently 60 times more expensive than maintaining patent protection in the US and 13 times that of the Japanese patent office. When does the Commission plan to obtain agreement and act on this? As we approach the end of another parliamentary term, with apparently little progress to report, what does the Commission recommend? Could the Commission indicate what it believes this situation is costing Europe in terms of intellectual property rights and innovation?

What further measures is the Commission now taking to ensure the full abolition of barriers imposed on customers by virtue of their country of residence or registration of payment card which prevent them accessing the best prices and range of goods and services, such as music downloads, rail and airline tickets, DVDs and computer games, particularly those sold online, sold anywhere in the EU?

In the Czech Presidency programme, it is stated that the Presidency will focus on overcoming barriers by means of information and communication technologies in accordance with the idea of a Europe without barriers.


Does the Czech Presidency have any specific plans to ensure that all citizens of Europe have access to broadband?

With more than 115 HSPA networks (HSPA being the latest technology enabling mobile service users to download data at high speed) and over 35 million users in Europe, UMTS technology, which has evolved out of GSM, has a key role to play and consumers appreciate it, not least because it offers many advantages.


If UMTS services are to go on developing, the regulatory framework requires that the 900 MHz GSM band be opened up to accommodate them. However, the revision of the GSM Directive 87/372/EEC(1), is very far behind schedule, and Member States are looking to the Commission, the Council, and Parliament to bring clarity to regulation.


Given the critical financial situation in Europe, a quick and responsible way should be found to allocate the band in question and reform the related directive so as to support the mobile communications business. All lawgivers therefore have the task of working towards a Europe-wide solution.


What political and technical measures will the Commission propose in order to avert further delays, which could affect the European electronic communications industry as a whole?

The Commission has put the development of ICT and of the Information Society, which has huge potential benefits for European economy and society, at the heart of its programmes. However, what is the Commission doing to ensure that certain sectors of European society - such as older people and people on low incomes - are not left behind or forgotten in this process?

In early January the Commission pledged to introduce new measures to support the dairy sector and producers' incomes across Europe in an effort to combat some of the negative effects the current economic crisis is having on the dairy sector. Has the Commission any plans to make similar pledges to support other agricultural sectors and producers who have also been negatively affected by the current economic crisis?

column5: Structural Funds in the new Member States
column7: What basic provisions will be put in place by the Commission to ensure that Structural Funds applied to the new Member States will not run high risks of going unspent, for example due to local industry lacking the expert knowledge required to table successful bids for EU grants?

The USA may propose a resolution at the ICAO meeting of 28 September 2004 to exclude any possibility of economic, fiscal or global emissions trading for international aviation. Is the Commission aware of this potential initiative? How will the Commission ensure that the EU retains its freedom to decide on economic, fiscal or global emissions instruments in the field of aviation, in order to develop a sustainable transport policy in the future?

The Dutch Presidency has stated its desire to work to ensure that transatlantic relations, including economic cooperation and trade relations will be strengthened on the basis of a positive agenda. Will the Council now provide a detailed statement on what it intends to include in its positive agenda and will it develop initiatives outside the sphere of economic cooperation and trade relations, for example, in the areas of culture and development aid?

Several EU Member States will be holding referendums in the next few months on the draft European constitution approved at the Council meeting of 17 and 18 June 2004.


It had been hoped that the referendums would be held on the same day throughout the EU but this now proves to be impossible as we have been overtaken by events.


However, it may still be feasible to coordinate the actual wording of the question put to voters.


Does the Council not agree that it is highly desirable that the same question should be put to voters in all the EU Member States holding a referendum on the draft constitution?


Will the Council take immediate steps to coordinate the arrangements so as to bring this about?

column5: Ignoring of Parliament's call relating to the advertising of the post of OLAF
column7:
Does the Commission think that paragraph 50 of Parliament's report (A5-0393/03), in which it is notes that ‘the current Director’s appointment will come to an end in March 2005; [Parliament] calls on the Commission to advertise the post of Director in the Official Journal in spring 2004, so that Parliament’s relevant committee can hear the suitable candidates in autumn 2004 on the basis of a proposal from the Supervisory Committee’ has been ignored? If not, why not? If so, why?


For reasons of transparency, can the Commission indicate in detail the steps and decisions taken since the adoption of the report regarding the appointment of the successor to Mr Brüner?


Does the Commission plan to advertise the post of Director of OLAF?

Following the successful outcome of the COP 11/MOP 1 in Montreal at the end of 2005, it is now essential to push ahead with the new processes launched: the negotiations on the post-2012 commitments and the dialogue on long-term joint actions under the Framework Convention on Climate Change.


Can the President-in-Office of the Council state what progress was made in this regard at the 24th Session of the Subsidiary Bodies of the Framework Convention on Climate Change held in Bonn from 15 to 26 May 2006?
Has the Council considered the COSAC report on the reform of the Court of Auditors, and will it make a statement on the matter?

Can the European Council outline the measures that it will take in order to explain to the citizens of Europe the provisions of the new Constitutional Treaty which was signed in Rome on 29 October 2004?

What is the Commission’s most up-to-date information regarding the percentage of public contracts awarded to SMEs in the EU (e.g. for 2005 and 2006)? More specifically, does it have information concerning the percentage of contracts awarded to medium and small enterprises respectively? Does it have data for each Member State?


In the United States, a percentage of public contracts may be set aside for SMEs within authorised WTO limits. In view of the WTO talks and the fresh proposals to be made by the Commission, will the European Union seek similar arrangements allowing Member States to set aside a percentage of public contracts for SMEs as recommended by France?

In the EU Member States, access to the Internet is currently subject to full-rate VAT, i.e. in Cyprus and Luxembourg, 15%; Germany, 16%; United Kingdom, 17.5%; Czech Republic, 19%; France, 19.6%; and Denmark, 25% (it is expected to be 22% in Poland).


Given the need to ensure equal access to the new technologies, regardless of place of residence, to enhance the competitiveness of our economies, especially compared with the United States, and ultimately to build an information society free of stereotypes and xenophobia, I believe that, within the EU, access to the Internet should be subject to zero-rate VAT, as I stated in Written Declaration 0056/2004.


Given the above, does the Commission intend to take steps to introduce zero-rate VAT on access to the Internet in all Member States of the European Union?

According to Proposal for a Decision COM(2004)0091/final, it is estimated that over 50 percent of global e-mail traffic will soon be spam. The 'opt-in rule' and the proposed programme are welcome developments but what practical measures will the Commission take to deal with the cross-border factor, the illegal content of some unsolicited mail and the protection of personal correspondence?


How does the Commission intend to protect freedom of expression on the Internet and how exactly will it draw the line between protection of personal correspondence and protection of minors and consumers, given the differences between Member States' legislation?

According to a report in the Svenska Dagbladet of 29 March, the Swedish government is preparing to permit other EU countries’ police authorities to carry out phone-tapping and data surveillance on Swedish citizens as part of the campaign to combat cross-border crime.


Does the Commission consider that this type of cross-border investigation permit has any foundation in the current legal basis for Europol and/or Schengen cooperation? Can other Member States be required to carry out similar cross-border investigations in return?

column5: Poles in top-level management posts within the Commission
column7: In December 2003, according to the official figures, the geographic breakdown of top-level management posts within the Commission was as follows: France 48, Germany 40, United Kingdom 38, Spain 26, Italy 27, to name but the largest 'old' Member States. What is the situation today, following the enlargement, as regards the participation of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and the other 'new' Member States?

As the Council should be aware, a sophisticated covert listening device was recently discovered in my constituency office in Belfast, and the British media reports that an admission has been made that this device was placed with the authorisation of British Intelligence.


Does the Council think that Member States acting in such a manner are showing due regard for democratic principles and the integrity of this institution? Does the Council accept that the constituency offices of Members of this House merit the same respect as offices based in the institutions? Will the Council give its opinion on the ethics of a listening device being planted inside offices that I use and also contact the British Government about this incident?

In its report on EU-India: A Strategic Partnership (A6-0256/2005) the European Parliament 'Welcomed the recent signing by the Commission and the Indian Government of an agreement under which the former is offering one thousand bursaries (33 million euro) to enable Indian students to attend European universities under the Erasmus Mundus programme, .... noted that the Indian Council for Cultural Relations is offering opportunities for European students to attend universities in India, but calls for greater interest to be shown in this so as to make a more active contribution to consolidating the foundations of the strategic partnership.'


Could the Commission give an update as to the current implementation of these proposals, with specific reference to collaboration in science and technology?


Does the Commission believe that professional and business exchanges could also be beneficial, both for cross-cultural understanding and the promotion of a two-way flow of information?


And does the Commission have any plans to replicate the success of the Executive Training Programme - People to People Exchange - that exists with Japan and Korea by extending the programme to India, with the appropriate funding?

column5: Linguistic diversity in the European Union
column7:
Within the European Union there are languages with a centuries-old history which are neither national nor official EU languages but which nonetheless often have many speakers living in different regions in a variety of Member States. In those regions, such languages sometimes enjoy official status and in certain cases they have a number of speakers, a literary tradition and a vitality comparable to those of national languages which enjoy official EU status, even though the latter may actually have only a similar or even a smaller number of speakers.


In view of the fact that respect for linguistic diversity is one of the EU's democratic and cultural foundations (as acknowledged in Article 22 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights: 'The Union shall respect cultural, religious and linguistic diversity') and since - in accordance with the EU's values - it would therefore be wrong to discriminate against a language merely on the grounds that it is not spoken throughout a Member States, does the Council not think that the EU should take greater account of the realities of such languages?


The Spanish Government has already submitted a Memorandum calling for the language arrangements within the EU institutions to be amended in order to accommodate Spain's co-official languages. What attitude is the Council likely to adopt in response to such a request?

column5: Possibly consequences of using mobile phones
column7:
Technological progress in mobile telephony has greatly facilitated communications between people. However, scientific views are occasionally published which have alarmed public opinion about the possible consequences for human health of using mobile phones.


Given these concerns and in order to ensure that the public is correctly and responsibly informed, will the Commission say:


Has it drawn up a scientific study investigating thoroughly whether and to what extent radiation from mobile phones affects human health?


If there is any evidence of possible consequences, does it intend to take some initiative to promote the correct use of mobile phones?

column5: Timetable for negotiations on the financial perspective
column7: The Luxembourg Presidency has stated its intention to reach an agreement on the financial perspective in June this year. How does the Presidency intend to work towards resolving the most important issues in the long-term budget and bringing about an agreement in the Council? Are there reasons to believe that the Presidency's timetable will be met?

column5: European aid to combat forest fires
column7:
In recent years a growing number of fires have occurred in the warmest regions of southern Europe, some produced by natural causes, but most caused by carelessness or started deliberately. The greenhouse effect and the consequent warming of some areas of the planet is making the situation worse. During this summer, in Andalucia (Spain) alone, more than 42 000 hectares have been burned and, regrettably, this will not be the final figure for the year. The EU already makes provision for aid for the prevention of forest fires, but needs to act as a matter of urgency to restore the damaged areas.


Given the problems of desertification caused by such fires, will the Commission allocate specific budgetary appropriations in 2005 in order to assist the recovery and reafforestation of areas destroyed by fire?

column5: The borders of the European Union
column7:
The countries and peoples of the European Union and potential candidates for membership should be informed about plans for future enlargement over at least the next 30 years. Future EU Member States should be involved in the formation of an efficient economic system and communications systems and energy and supply networks in order not to incur unnecessary additional accession costs. This will require a clearer definition of the conditions for accession to the European Union and of the EU's borders, in accordance with the expectations of the Member States (e.g. energy security). A natural EU border would appear to be one that follows the borders of countries all or part of whose territory is in the continent of Europe and which have an interest in becoming EU Member States. Such an approach would safeguard cohesion policy.


What steps does the Commission intend to take with a view to defining the future borders of the European Union?

column5: Promotion and protection of fundamental rights
column7:
In connection with the debate on the promotion and protection of fundamental rights, the role of the existing national and European institutions is under discussion and there are calls for the establishment of a new agency for fundamental rights.


Which institutions are already responsible at national and European level for the promotion and protection of fundamental rights, what are their exact remits and to what extent will the agency for fundamental rights represent added value?

Is the Council intending to start negotiations - and, if so, when - with Parliament and the Commission in order to conclude an interinstitutional agreement on the operating framework for the future European regulatory agencies on the basis of the Commission's draft (COM(2005)0059 final?


Does the Council consider that such negotiations should be concluded before the end of 2000- 2006 the financial perspective?

column5: Biometric data in passports and visas
column7:
What is the cost of including biometric data in passports and visas under the new rules? No specific information is given; the decision merely states that the costs will fall with technological developments and 'pooling'. There is a more detailed study entitled 'Study for the Extended Impact Assessment of Visa Information System' dated December 2004 but it does not give any exact amounts.


What is the Council's estimate of the cost of inserting face recognition and fingerprint data in passports/visas/residence permits? How many border posts/authorities will have to be equipped? On how many annual passports, visas and residence permits are the calculations based? (In particular with the new 5-year limit on passports). Who will bear the cost?


I fail to understand the Legal Service's opinion that these decisions are consistent with Article 18(3) of the EC Treaty; is a specific prohibition on taking a decision not sufficient? How is the new Constitution to be interpreted in the light of this decision when an express prohibition is not an express prohibition? Is that not confusing for voters in a referendum?


Was the decision lawful in the light of Article 18(3) and the lack of financial information in the impact analysis?

A study carried out by the Kassel College of Higher Education in July 2004 on German regional aid (EU and German federal programmes) shows that up to 96% of the appropriations paid in subsidies have no lasting impact in economic terms owing to geographical relocations and the deadweight effect. The current proposal for a regulation laying down general provisions (COM(2004)0492 final) seeks to prevent subsidies being paid for business relocation during the new programming period. However, this scheme relates only to the 7-year period during which the subsidised investment has to remain in a given location. How will it be possible for the relocation of a business before that period to be taken into account under this scheme? How would it be possible to prevent subsidies being used solely for relocation?

column5: Inspections to monitor implementation of environmental legislation
column7: There are very many violations of environmental legislation in Greece and other EU countries, which cause environmental pollution and lead to time-consuming procedures, in most cases judicial procedures. Furthermore, the central and regional authorities only carry out inspections and controls at the project approval stage. In view of the above, what actions does the Commission intend to take to ensure a more complete and substantive implementation of environmental legislation in the Member States and make compulsory regular inspections and controls throughout the duration of various projects in case they have environmental consequences and thus are contrary to existing legislation?

column5: Ideas to enhance the EU's ability to respond to crises
column7:
What plans, if any, has the Council in relation to innovative ideas to enhance the EU's ability to respond to crises such as the Asian tsunami crisis?


For example, the Luxembourg Presidency cited the idea of 'battle groups' to enhance the EU's capability in this field. (NB The Luxembourg Presidency talked about Aid Battle Groups during the exchange of views in the Foreign Affairs Committee on 19 January 2005).

column5: Administrative reform of the European institutions
column7:
Opinion polls show that citizens see the European institutions as big bureaucratic centres which have a lot of power and are run with a lot of taxpayers’ money. The Prodi Commission began to tackle this problem and Commissioner Kinnock was put in charge of administrative reform of the European institutions.


Has the ‘Kinnock reform’ even begun? Is it in progress? Or has it perhaps already been completed? And if it has been completed, what effects has it had? In your opinion, how many unnecessary administrative obstacles are there in EU regulations? Do you intend to draw up a programme of measures to combat red tape?
All too frequently, decisions take by the EU are not put into effect in the Member States. What steps will the Council take to improve the implementation of EU decisions?

column5: Getting the message across about the EU
column7:
Various opinion polls suggest that citizens do not feel themselves to be closely involved in the European Union or with its institutions. The information campaigns and the debate being held on the Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe in connection with the various referenda risk being obscured by other issues, including Turkey's potential accession and the question of whether or not to approve the directive on services.


Does the Commission recognise that the debate on the Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe lacks the necessary clarity? What methods of communication does it intend to use to get across the message about the European Union and its benefits to citizens?

According to the British newspaper ‘The Sunday Times’, the United Kingdom secret service MI5 has admitted that it has secretly monitored the offices of the Sinn Féin political party, including the office of a Member of the European Parliament.


Will the Council raise the issue with the governments of the Member States in order to establish the rights of Members of the European Parliament under the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Communities, as referred to in Article 5 of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure?

In its conclusions of 13 December 2004, the Council stressed the strategic importance of Ukraine as a neighbour and partner of the EU and expressed its wish that cooperation with that country should be strengthened after the free and democratic election of a new president. On 17 December 2004, the European Council expressed its wish for the gradual intensification and strengthening of political and economic relations between the EU and Ukraine. The new President of Ukraine, Viktor Yushenko, has since stated that Ukraine aspires to full membership of the EU.


Does the Council have a strategic plan in regard to the geographical limits of enlargement, in addition to the Copenhagen criteria and Article 6(1) of the Treaty on European Union and, if so, what is that plan?


Does the enlargement process affect the pace of integration of the Union as a whole and, if so, how?

During her hearing by Parliament before her appointment as a Commissioner, Mrs Reding said that promoting digital literacy would be one of her priorities. However, so far most of the measures to overcome the digital divide have only concerned access to communications technologies rather than promoting actual digital skills.


The report 'Rethinking the European ICT Agenda', published during the Dutch Presidency, stated that one of the main objectives of the information society was to change the approach from 'access to technology for all' to 'making the necessary information and skills available to all'.


Various surveys have shown that digital skills considerably enhance people's work. In view of the above, what will the Commission do to promote the idea of 'making the necessary knowledge available to all' and increase digital literacy in the European Union?

column5: Political action is support of European values
column7:
During the Dutch presidency five meetings were held to discuss European values leading to the publication of a report entitled ‘Europe - a good idea’, education being one of the five sectors in which action is called for. The Ministers of Education emphasised the importance of incorporating within the education system the European values referred to in the European Constitution.


What measures are being envisaged by the new Luxembourgish presidency to follow up this initiative and how is it intended that they would be implemented at national level so as to ensure that, from an early stage in their education, young Europeans come to be guided by the principles of freedom, solidarity and mutual respect.

'Sport can play a vital role in encouraging development. Sport can bring benefits both to individuals, who can enjoy participating in healthier activities, and wider communities as it can often build better relations. Sports, thanks to global cost-cutting capacities in human development can add tremendous positive value to international work' (Adolf Ogi, the UN Secretary-General's Special Adviser on Sport for Development and Peace, 9.3.2005).


2005 is the United Nations International Year of Sport and Physical Education. Sport and physical education are considered to be means to promote education, health, development and peace. One of the goals of the International Year is to create the right conditions for more sport-based development programmes and projects. Several countries, for example Norway, Canada, United Kingdom and the Netherlands, are active in this field. Sport projects apparently can contribute to reaching the MDGs, especially on themes like health, education, gender, environment and peace. They are also known as 'low-cost, high impact' projects.


Is the Council aware of the fact that the UN stimulates countries and international sports associations to be active in this field through assisting in capacity building, recognising the possible contribution of sport to social cohesion, intercultural dialogues, environmental understanding and re-integration of children in post-conflict situations and the contribution of sport education to economic and social development?


Does the Council share the opinion that sport and physical education can contribute to development and to reaching the MDGs? Is the Council considering promoting sport-based development programmes and projects? Can the Council stimulate a study on the results of projects that have been realised by development organisations and sport organisations on development and sport, the potential of policy in this field and the possible role for the EU and/or the Member States and/or NGOs on development and sport?

column5: Funding of Defence Training Centre at St Athan (UK)
column7: Could the Commission clarify whether any European monies have been allocated to support the development of the proposed Defence Training Centre (non-military training) at St Athan in South Wales? Should any funding have been made available, could the Commission supply details of the amounts involved, the funds from which these amounts have been drawn down and the dates of any decision in this respect?

The contract for Wharf 2 of the Port of Piraeus container terminal (SEMPO) to the Chinese company Cosco is to be submitted for approval to the Greek Parliament over the next few days. It has provoked a strong reaction from workers and from a number of organisations because of the unprecedented tax concessions being offered by the Greek Government to the Chinese company. Under the contract, the Chinese company enjoys a number of advantages, including exemption from stamp duty on all loans to fund the project, immediate VAT reimbursement — with interest for any delay beyond 60 days —‘indefinite loss carryover for setoff against taxable profits etc. <QT.END'</QT.END> At the same time, the Piraeus Port Organisation, which will be responsible for managing SEMPO Wharf 1, is being faced with considerable outlay for the relocation of docks and buildings, dredging activities etc.

Does the Commission consider that the tax concessions being granted to the company responsible for administering Wharf 2 infringe Community competition law, given that no other Greek ports enjoy such advantages? What measures will it take should competition issues arise?

The Transparency initiative launched on 9 November 2005 by Commission Vice-President Siim Kallas was most welcome. The complex of measures proposed by Mr Kallas included codes of conduct for lobbying groups and civil society organisations.


On the basis of Mr Kallas’s European Transparency Initiative, the European Parliament adopted at its plenary sitting on 8 May 2008 a motion for a resolution (P6_TA(2008)0197) on development of the framework for the activities of interest representatives (lobbyists) in the European institutions (2007/2115(INI)).


In its motion for a resolution, Parliament stated that it:


‘[a]cknowledges that a rapporteur may, as he or she sees fit (on a voluntary basis), use a "legislative footprint", i.e. an indicative list (attached to Parliament's reports) of registered interest representatives who were consulted, and had significant input, during the preparation of the report; considers it particularly advisable that such list be included in legislative reports; stresses, nevertheless, that it is even more important for the Commission to attach such "legislative footprint" to its legislative initiatives’.


When does the Commission propose to introduce the attachment of such a ‘legislative footprint’ to its legislative initiatives?

column5: National strategy for implementation of the new common organisation
column7:
Given that Greece should have published by 31 December 2008 its national strategy for implementation of the new common organisation of the market in fruit and vegetables from 2009 onwards:

1. Does the Commission know why publication and adoption of the mandatory national strategy has been delayed?

2. How will the Commission ensure equal entitlements throughout the European Union to incentives for entrepreneurship and fruit and vegetable supply management?

3. What means are available to Greek producers to seek the prompt implementation by the Greek Government of a Community policy designed to ensure them equal business opportunities within the European Union?

A number of Member States are seeking to refinance their debts by purchasing government bonds at higher interest rates than those payable in Germany, the country of reference, thereby increasing their public debt and budget deficit.


1. What view does the Commission take of the possible issue of Eurobonds which may be purchased by Member States in economic difficulties? In the Commission's view, what are its advantages and practical drawbacks?


2. Does the Commission consider that a decision to issue Eurobonds will endanger the stability of the eurozone and, if so, how can this danger be offset?

The European Union has expressly recognised the importance and usefulness of homeopathic medicines and has regulated their placing on the market by means of a number of directives, the most recent of which is Directive 2004/27/EC(1), which amends the Community code relating to medicinal products for human use (Directive 2001/83/EC(2)).


Italy officially transposed that directive by means of Decree Law 219/2006, Chapter 2 of which lays down special provisions applying to homeopathic medicines, including the option, as required under EC law, to use a simplified procedure to register some homeopathic medicines (for oral administration/external use/without therapeutic indications and with a given degree of dilution).


However, Article 17 of Decree Law 219/2006 required the publication in the Official Gazette, within three months of the decree law's entry into force, of a specimen registration application form drawn up by the AIFA (Italian Medicines Agency). Inexplicably, that form, the contents of which were specified in the transposing act, has, several years later, still to be published. This situation constitutes an inadmissible barrier to implementation of the provisions of Directive 2004/27/EC.


Some nine million Italians use homeopathic medicines, and the failure to publish the above form has, in practice, made it impossible to place new homeopathic medicines on the market, thus seriously damaging the interests of both producers and consumers.


Given the above, and with a view to ensuring that EU citizens are free to choose treatments and producers are able to develop new products, would the Commission state whether:

1. it is aware of the above issue;

2. it intends to take steps to put an end to this situation, which is hampering the establishment of a harmonised internal market and causing serious damage to European producers and consumers?

column5: Misleading picture provided by Eurostat data
column7:
On 19 February, the European Statistical Office Eurostat published an overview of regional gross domestic product per capita. This showed the Province of Groningen as being ranked at number five in terms of GDP per capita, although Groningen is the Dutch province with the highest unemployment and is suffering from structural problems and a declining population. This gives rise to the following questions.


— Is the Commission aware of the natural gas extraction in Groningen and the resultant revenue accruing to the Netherlands State treasury?

— Do the statistics for the Province of Groningen include this natural gas revenue?

— Is the Commission aware that only a very small proportion of this gas revenue benefits residents of Groningen? If so, why is this revenue included in the calculations of GDP per capita for the Province of Groningen?

— What will the Commission do to remedy this misunderstanding? Is altering Eurostat's current method of calculation an option, for example?

— Can the Commission confirm that this calculation does not reflect the real situation in Groningen and therefore cannot and will not be taken as a basis for future policy and future funding?

Could the Commission indicate whether it is concerned about moves by EU airlines to strictly enforce the one cabin baggage item rule and prevent passengers who may have a bag after making a purchase in an airport shop (duty free), or baby supplies which does not fit into their main cabin bag from boarding, forcing them to pay EUR 30 per extra bag carried on board?


Does the Commission agree that this policy will be an extremely difficult problem for airports, both regional and international, that rely on the sale of duty-free goods for the majority of their revenue and thus provision of services?

column5: Campaign to publicise the European elections
column7:
I am receiving increasingly frequent invitations from non-profit-making organisations to attend events — sometimes with cryptic names and complicated raisons d’être; the intention, as far as I can understand, is to awaken interest in, and seek support for, the forthcoming European elections. The invitation that I received this morning clearly stated that the event in question was being supported by the Commission Representation, as, I imagine, is likewise the case for many of the events organised by Parliament’s outlying offices.


1. Could the Commission confirm that it is supporting events of this kind?


2. What is the total amount earmarked for that purpose in the 2009 budget, and how has it been divided among the Member States?


3. Could the Commission supply a list of the recipient Italian non-profit-making organisations, specifying the aims which they are pursuing?


4. Does it oversee the conduct of the activities financed?

Following the decision by the Belgian judiciary to close its investigation into the German journalist Hans-Martin Tillack, the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) had called on the Commission and the EU Anti-Fraud Office OLAF to apologise to Mr Tillack for suspecting him of fraud. Will the Commission and/or OLAF now issue such an apology? If not, why not?


On 13 July 2005 Commissioner Kallas had announced before the Committee on Budgetary Control that, following the end of the investigation into Mr Tillack, he would consider whether those responsible had been guilty of misconduct. Does Commissioner Kallas now intend to order such an investigation?


The IFJ had also called on the Commission to order an independent investigation into OLAF's behaviour in this matter. Does the Commission intend to act in response to this appeal?


How does the Commission judge the charge made by the European Court of Human Rights that the accusations against Mr Tillack were based exclusively on rumours?


Since the person who started these rumours is a former member of the Commission press service, will the Commission examine the role of the persons who were the hierarchical superiors of this employee at the time, namely Director-General Jonathan Faull and Commissioner Schreyer?


Does the Commission consider that the principle laid down in the EU regulation governing OLAF — namely that OLAF's conclusions should be exclusively evidence-based — was respected in this case?

column5: Free mobility of academics throughout EU universities
column7:
An academic living in my constituency has raised concerns regarding labour mobility in the European academic job market? He fears that this already difficult problem will worsen in the current climate, when debates about the free movement of labour versus economic nationalism are taking place in many Member States, including the UK.


The UK traditionally has a very open academic jobs market, not just for EU nationals but also for academics from all over the world, and British universities benefit from recruiting top quality European and non-European academics, whereas the university sectors in countries such as Spain, France and Italy are largely closed shops. They are allegedly closed shops, to some degree, even for their own citizens, since jobs are allegedly rarely or never advertised in the public domain, and it is alleged that there are virtually no UK citizens working as academics in these countries because jobs are not advertised and are effectively ‘reserved’ only for nationals of those states.


Can the Commission confirm the legality of the non-advertisement of academic posts to a wider pan European audience and whether such permanent academic posts can be reserved solely for nationals of the Member States in question? Are there any plans to make these jobs compulsorily advertised at national or EU-wide level? What EU programmes are there for EU-funded exchanges of academics on a short term basis, and are any of these postings ever converted into permanent positions with academic tenure in foreign universities?

column5: Sending of a European peacekeeping force
column7:
Multinational peacekeeping forces are active throughout the Middle East in peace enforcement operations. Whether in Iraq, Lebanon, or Afghanistan, soldiers from, among other places, a number of EU Member States are being deployed in ‘hot spots’ for the purpose of restoring and maintaining peace through peacekeeping operations.


Does the Council not believe that it should explore the possibility, under the European security and defence policy, of sending a substantial European peacekeeping force to the border separating Israel from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank in order to make the Israelis and Palestinians accept coexistence and the mutual recognition of two independent states?
Under the proposed Lisbon Treaty, would the European Parliament have power of co-decision with the Council on the labelling of GMOs in food and animal feed?

Can the Commission please update the European Parliament on its response to the European Parliament resolution on the Green Paper ‘Towards a Europe free from tobacco smoke’ (P6_TA(2007)0471)?


In particular, can it state the action it has taken on the following points:


paragraph 3, which called for environmental tobacco smoke to be classified in the Dangerous Substances Directive (67/548/EEC)1 as a class 1 carcinogen;


paragraph 4, which called on the Commission to list and quantify the concrete effects of smoking among youth and propose European objectives aimed at curbing the uptake and consumption of tobacco among young people;


paragraph 7, which called for a revision of the Workplace Safety and Health Directive (89/391/EEC)2 so as to require all employers to ensure that the workplace is free from tobacco smoke;


paragraph 13, which called on the Commission to examine further measures such as an EU-wide ban on the use of tobacco in private vehicles in the presence of minors, a ban on the sale of tobacco products to under 18s, a ban on cigarette vending machines accessible to minors and the removal of tobacco products from self-service displays?

column5: European funding and the benefits of the EU for London
column7:
Communicating the benefits of EU membership is an important part of making the EU more accessible to its citizens, and should be a priority for the Commission.


Would the Commission provide a breakdown of EU-funded projects (ESF, ERDF and other funding streams) in London over the last decade? How much money was spent, in which locations, and what were the positive outcomes for Londoners?


Furthermore, does the Commission possess any statistics regarding the overall economic benefit of EU membership to specific regions such as London? If not, are there any plans to undertake such research?

Is the Commission satisfied as to the legality and compliance with EC law and expectations of the distribution on a ‘first come, first served’ basis of Axis 1 rural development funds, in respect of modernisation grants, by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development in Northern Ireland?

column5: Use of languages in administrative drafting
column7:
The requirement that Commission officials draft texts in a specific language that is not their mother tongue, and often not even their first foreign language, is widely known to create problems as regards the quality of the texts drafted — to such an extent that ‘drafting committees’ have had to be set up within the translation service for a single language.


It seems clear that these ‘committees’ are starting to take on a strategic role and excessive powers which rob original drafters of the precise content of their texts.


In the light of the above:

1. does the Commission not consider that its texts, which often deal with technical and highly specialised matters, should whenever possible be drafted in the editor's mother tongue in order to maintain a high level of quality and reliability in respect of the subject matter;

2. can it explain how on earth, despite declaring itself in favour of multilingualism, it continues in practice to resort, for ‘pragmatic’ reasons, to solely using one language, with a mere smattering of so-called ‘procedural languages’;

3. will it undertake to give effect to multilingualism, both internally and in its relations with the public, by laying down clear and unambiguous rules based on objective criteria;

4. will it adopt measures to make multilingualism a reality within its departments and in its relations with citizens?

column5: Update on the UK e-Borders Programme
column7:
In April 2007, I tabled questions concerning the e-Borders Programme, which has existed in the UK since 2004 (reference: E-2115/07).


As a follow-up to those questions I would like to inform the Commission about the latest developments in this programme, in particular in the aviation sector. The UK authorities are requiring air carriers to participate in the e-Borders Programme by providing advance passenger information (API). From the last quarter of 2009 onwards, for designated routes (which might include intra-EU flights), carriers will be obliged to provide the UK authorities with even more data – what is termed ‘other passenger information’ (OPI), also known as passenger name records (PNR) – data routinely held in carrier reservation systems, in so far as they are known to them.


1. Does the Commission agree that, as there has been no decision yet regarding the EU PNR proposal (COM(2007)654), the request for OPI (PNR) data by the UK is premature? If not, why not?


Both Directive 2004/82/EC1 and the EU PNR proposal are very clear in stating that disclosure of passenger data by air carriers concerns only ‘international flights’ (i.e. from outside the EU). The ‘new’ UK plans are not clear at all as to whether or not they will require ‘intra-EU’ passenger data. This is leading to great uncertainty for the aviation sector on what it can expect from EU Member States regarding an obligation to disclose passenger-related data (API, OPI, PNR, and credit card data, even though this type of data is no longer part of PNR, and/or departure control systems (DCS)).


2. Would the Commission be willing to look into the UK situation in greater depth, in particular concerning the consequences of this programme for the free movement of persons in the EU? If so, could the Commission inform me about its findings? If not, why not?


Each new disclosure or new type of disclosure requires investment in a number of areas (system adjustments, procedural changes, data communication costs) by the aviation sector. As the economic situation in the aviation sector is currently very weak, that investment might lead to serious financial problems and/or bankruptcy.


3. Does the Commission agree that this investment imposes a disproportionate burden on the aviation sector? If not, why not?

In view of the proceedings initiated by the Commission against Microsoft for abuse of its dominant position on the software market following the incorporation of Internet Explorer into the Windows systems, can the Commission provide the following information:


1. In which Commission computers has Internet Explorer been installed?


2. Why does it not give the members of staff concerned the possibility of initially selecting their webbrowsers of preference?

column5: Official travel by European Commissioners in 2008
column7:
Could the Commission provide an overview of official travel by all Commissioners during 2008?


In particular, could it indicate for each Commissioner, the destinations, the duration of the journey, the reasons for the journey, the Commissioner’s activities in the country of destination, and the cost of all the Commissioner’s official travel, including the costs incurred by the delegation accompanying the Commissioner?

The British Government is claiming that its plans to introduce identity cards over the next year or so must include the EU logo (ring of stars).


This claim implies that the ID card is an EU requirement, but the British Government is unclear on that point.


1. Is there any requirement under EU legislation for the British Government to introduce ID cards either now or in the future?


2. On what legal authority must the EU logo (ring of stars) be included if the answer to my first question is ‘no’?


3. If the answer to my first question is ‘yes’, by what legal authority does the EU claim the power to reverse the relationship between the individual and the state which the introduction of ID cards clearly achieves?

None of the protocols are yet in effect because not one has been ratified by all Member States.


Could the Commission list which Member States by name have not yet ratified which protocols?

I have received a letter from a constituent which states that the area-based payment in Ireland, which was introduced in 1968, has been cut in the 2009 budget. The farmers concerned believe that this is a violation of the principle of protection of legitimate expectation, as cited in the case Mavridis v European Parliament.


I request an interpretation of protection of legitimate expectation.


Could this right be applied to the situation of the Irish farmers concerned?

Europeana, the European Union's first digital library that brings together two million works from national libraries, museums and other cultural archives, was forced to close its portal temporarily when it was overloaded by consultation requests. Does the Commission know when it will reopen?


Will the Commission continue to promote the digitisation of European works in the Member States in order to supply this portal and increase the percentage of digitised works held by European cultural institutions in 2010? In the Commission's view, how will the copyright problems be resolved?

The safety and security of each and every one of us matters. The European Parliament is the symbol of European democracy, and at the same time the symbol of unity in diversity. In view of the unfortunate incident which occurred on 12 February 2009 inside the European Parliament, we would like to see tighter security and protective measures both inside and around EP buildings.


Could the Council therefore indicate:


  1. whether it intends to step up security over the whole of the area in which the European Parliament’s buildings are located, both on the inside and on the outside of those buildings (and here I refer to mobile teams permanently patrolling the surroundings of the European Parliament buildings);


  1. whether it would consider it appropriate, in addition to the security company operating inside the European Parliament’s buildings, for solutions to be found, in cooperation with the Belgian state, for mobile patrols of the surroundings of the European Parliament’s buildings to be drawn from local police forces?

Have any of the following organisations received money from the European Commission since 2005, how much did they receive, and which budget headings did the funding come from?

A.I.A.S. Associazione Italiana Assistenza agli Spastici
Academia Istrapolitana Nova
ACFCI — Direction des affaires européennes
AEBIOM (European Biomass Association)
AEGEE Europe
AEGEE Utrecht
AeT Ambiente e Territorio CCIAA Roma
AFAEMME — Association of Organisations of Mediterranean Businesswomen
ASAJA ESPAÑA

According to the Danish media, Commissioner Neelie Kroes has stated that the holiday period in the EU is too long and that it should be moved from its present position to other points in the year. At present, many people in EU countries are at leisure simultaneously, which detracts from the EU's competitiveness, according to some sources. Is this the Commission's view? Does the Commission intend to propose harmonisation of holiday periods or rules concerning the periods to which holidays should be moved in the EU?
Does EU public procurement legislation include ‘Design for All’ and accessibility requirements in the technical specifications of tender documents?

column5: The financial crisis and the EU institutional framework
column7:
22 February 2009 saw a meeting in Berlin bringing together the French President, the German Chancellor, the Prime Ministers of the UK, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain, the Czech Presidency, the President of the Euro Group (Mr Juncker), the Commission President and the ECB President, in order to define an EU position for the G-20 summit to be held on 2 April 2009, in the light of the disturbing signs of intensification of the financial crisis and its social consequences.


This meeting of a certain number of EU heads of state and government together with the heads of some of the EU institutions, for the purposes of discussing the crisis and preparing a possible response at Union level, has been preceded by others, with a variable number of participants. This is not in line with the model or the format laid down in the Treaties.


Can the Commission state:


– if it considers the existing institutional framework no longer to be valid, or if it believes that framework still offers solutions suitable for the definition and coordination of a common response;


– how it assesses the value and scope of this kind of ad hoc meeting aimed at finding solutions to the crisis, held outside the institutional framework of the Treaty and without the presence of all Member States;


– whether, given the severity of the crisis and the anomalous circumstance of acting outside the predefined institutional framework, it believes it would be justified to convene an urgent meeting of the Conference of Representatives of the Governments of the Member States (Article 48 TUE), with a view to adopting, by joint agreement, a set of specific amendments to the Treaties which would endow the Union with the means to respond to the present challenges?

column5: Financing a Member State in difficulty
column7:
The press have recently reported that, as a result of the economic crisis and the critical situation in some European countries struggling to manage their debt, the German Government is considering coming to the aid of those countries that are more at risk of insolvency and therefore of bankruptcy.

In particular, the possibility of a solvent State helping a Member State in difficulty by underwriting bilateral debenture loans was suggested. This is obviously due to the fact that European national economies are closely interlinked, and the economic crises hitting some Member States will inevitably have repercussions for the others.

The ECB has already made a statement, reminding Member States that they are not allowed to take over the financial commitments of their European partners.


Given the above, how does the Commission intend to invigilate this idea of assisting States in financial difficulties?


Furthermore, in the Commission's opinion, what could be done at EU level to find a solution to the problem of excessive debt in some countries, which is damaging not only to them but also to the EU as a whole?

column5: Community funding for energy infrastructure projects and broadband internet
column7:
In the context of the efforts being made at EU level to manage the effects of the economic and financial crisis, the Commission presented, on 26 November 2008, a package of measures billed as the 'European Plan for Economic Recovery'. Among the measures at Union level for supporting the European economy mentioned in this document is the allocation of Community funding to the sum of EUR 5 bn to support projects in the fields of energy and broadband internet.


The European Council of 11 and 12 December 2008 approved the funding of priority projects in the above areas, specifying that the necessary budget effort must be made under the existing financial perspective for 2007-2013.


With a view to implementing these measures agreed by the European Council, the Commission presented, on 23 December 2008, an initial funding proposal and a first list of priority projects in the fields of energy and broadband. Thanks to the lack of coherence within this list of proposed projects, it was not possible to obtain the qualified majority required in Council for approval of the Commission's initiative.


On 28 January 2009. the Commission presented a new communication on the package of priority projects, under the title 'Investing today for tomorrow’s Europe'.


Can the Commission explain why the proposed funding does not include projects for the storage of gas, given that certain Member States, including Romania, have submitted projects to that effect?

At the end of January, the Heartland Payment Systems credit card processing company revealed that its files had been breached. It appears that unknown hackers had managed to infiltrate its systems in 2008 and install malicious software enabling them to steal credit card data and thereby make copies of up to 100 million cards. Given that Heartland Payment Systems is the sixth largest credit card processing company in the USA, it is clear that similar breaches could easily occur in smaller European undertakings. In view of the fact that most Europeans make Internet purchases, what measures are being taken to protect their credit card data from expert hackers? What action has been taken by the Commission in the past, and what action does it intend to take in future in response to Internet data breaches?

More and more European citizens travel to non-EU countries. If their passport is lost or stolen, the only way to travel back to the EU is to acquire an ‘emergency travel document’ from their own national embassy or consulate, and if those do not exist then they should be able to obtain the document from any other embassy or consulate of a Member State on the spot (Article 20 TEC). This ‘emergency travel document’ was created 12 years ago by Council Decision 96/409(1). However, organisations of expatriate EU citizens complain about the difficulties EU citizens have when travelling back due to the border authorities' unwillingness to accept this document.


I would like to know:


1. Is this ‘emergency travel document’ also valid for transit to other EU countries through major hubs located outside the Schengen area (for example London Heathrow)?

2. How are the EU external borders authorities made aware of the existence of this ‘emergency travel document’, and what measures has the Commission taken until now in order to inform them?

3. Is this ‘emergency travel document’ going to be published in the handbook for EU border guards, with a picture so the authorities will be aware of it?

4. Will this ‘emergency travel document’ acquire biometrics and security features, as in the national EU passports it is supposed to replace?

column5: European Year of Equal Opportunities for All (2007)
column7:
In its proposal for a decision of the EP and the Council concerning the European Year of Equal Opportunities for All (2007), the Commission states that the Year will seek to highlight the message to the public at large that all people, irrespective of their sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age and sexual orientation, are entitled to equal treatment. Promoting respect and tolerance is high on the agenda. According to the proposal, all manner of policy measures and initiatives are required in order to promote greater participation of under-represented groups in society. Besides support for national initiatives and measures, all manner of ‘Community level action’ is promised, such as information and promotion campaigns (COM(2005)0225 final, C6-0178/05, pp. 5, 11-12 and 17).


As numerous studies indicate, many Islamic women suffer discrimination by and in their (Islamic) community and this hampers their full participation in the labour market and society in general.


As a study by Professor Werner Bergmann of Berlin University of Technology dating from 2002 showed, anti-Semitic acts are committed primarily by young Muslims, many of them of Arab origin.


How will the Commission approach these serious problems in its campaign? Will it launch a specific campaign to make it clear to the Islamic community that women should enjoy equal rights and opportunities? How will the Commission persuade Islamic communities in Europe to display greater respect and tolerance towards Jewish communities?
