Under the system of monolingualism, barely mitigated by the alleged trilingualism of the ‘procedural languages’ prevailing within the Commission, Italian suffers more discrimination than any of the Union's other official languages. Although it is the language of one of the four ‘big’ Member States, as well as a founding Member State, Italian is not included among the ‘procedural languages’, but is treated as a lesser language, as if the Union's 60 million Italians were less important than the citizens of France, Germany and the United Kingdom, whose populations are comparable to that of Italy — except for Germany, which has a somewhat larger population.


The supposedly ‘pragmatic’ mechanism adopted by the Commission for using the official languages of the Member States totally contradicts the very nature of the European institutions, which, as such, have the precise duty to furnish themselves with clear and unequivocal rules, based on objective criteria, as is the custom among civilised countries that respect the rule of law.


Can the Commission say:

1. according to what criteria English, French and German were chosen as procedural languages;

2. according to what criteria Italian was excluded in this context?

1. What, if any, will be the benefit to the UK of Turkey acceding to the EU?


2. What, if any, will be the benefit to the UK of Romania acceding to the EU?


3. What, if any, will be the benefit to the UK of Bulgaria acceding to the EU?

The Commission presents its view on how Plan-D is to be implemented in document COM(2005)0494 final. The Commission expresses its intention to listen to the views of the Member States' populations on EU cooperation and to draw conclusions therefrom. Among the proposals referred to, the Commission notes that it would be appropriate to use ‘European Goodwill Ambassadors’, who may include well-known figures, such as sports celebrities, who would disseminate information and take part in meetings. Since the declared objective of Plan-D is to listen to the people, it is important that all opinions are heard and that the project does not become a ‘propaganda campaign’ for the potential benefits of EU cooperation.


Does the Commission take the view that both EU supporters and people with a more critical attitude towards the EU can be used as ‘Goodwill Ambassadors’, or in another role to further the debate on the EU so that the discussion becomes multifaceted and not one-sided? If the goal of Plan-D is to listen to the populations of the Member States, why should ‘Goodwill Ambassadors’ disseminate information and take part in meetings when such direct dialogue with the public can be carried out by democratically elected politicians? If the outcome of the dialogue with the public in the Member States is that the citizens of Europe want less EU integration and more national self-determination, what impact will that have on the Commission's agenda?

column5: EU staff settling on the outskirts of Brussels
column7:
Experience shows that the majority of EU officials now working in Brussels choose to live in one of the 19 municipalities of the Brussels capital region or on the outskirts of Brussels. However, particularly in the latter area, which is part of the Flemish and therefore Dutch-speaking region, a number of problems arise. There are problems of a social nature (the large presence of EU officials in some municipalities is inflating rents and property prices, as a result of which many young Flemish families are forced to leave their local area), but also problems of language policy. Many Flemish suburban municipalities have to cope with the problem of French-speaking Belgian incomers who refuse to recognise the Dutch-speaking character of the area. The gradual Frenchification of parts of Flemish Brabant is a significant political problem. In a number of municipalities (so-called municipalities with facilities) the original Flemish inhabitants have already become a minority. The presence of large numbers of EU staff who cannot speak Dutch has often exacerbated the problems. Not because of any ill will on the part of these EU officials, but mostly for other reasons such as lack of information.


There are ways of tackling these problems. New or even existing EU officials could be offered incentives to settle in neighbouring Walloon Brabant. They could also be made aware of the political situation in the outskirts of Brussels, and encouraged to take the Dutch language courses organised by the municipalities, and so on.


Is the Commission, unlike former Commissioner Neil Kinnock, prepared to examine these and possibly other measures to make the process of EU staff taking up residence and settling in the area around Brussels go more smoothly?

The European Commission has made ‘communication’ one of the objectives of its term in office. In addition, transparency and closeness to the public are matters of concern for all the European institutions. The measures that the institutions take have an impact on everyday life and must be communicated to people in order to promote their acceptance.


In this regard, how does the Commission record all projects (within programmes) in the Member States that are co-financed by the European Union?


What projects have been financed in the European Union since 2000?


What projects have been financed for North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany) in the current financial period?


Is this information already available, and how is it published?

Under the current EU Drugs Action Plan (2005-08) Member States have to develop further alternatives to imprisonment for drug addicts and drug services for people in prisons by:

(a) making effective use and developing further alternatives to prison for drug addicts who commit drug related offences;

(b) developing prevention, treatment and harm reduction services for people in prison, reintegration services on release from prison and methods to monitor/analyse drug use among prisoners.


In Bulgaria, which intends to become an EU Member State in 2007, the government's legislative programme for January-June 2006 does not include legislative improvements in response to the current EU drugs action plan.


During the last few years Bulgaria has seen growing numbers of drug addicts, including drug addicts who commit drug-related offences and drug addicts among the prison population.


In Bulgaria there is a lack of: alternatives to prison for drug addicts who commit drug-related offences; a lack of prevention, treatment and harm-reduction services for people in prison and a lack of reintegration services on release from prison.


What steps will the Commission take to urge Bulgaria to improve the related legislation and prison services, with a view to providing further alternatives to imprisonment for drug addicts and drug services for people in prisons, in response to the EU drugs action plan (2005-08)?

column5: Cut in Italy's voluntary contributions to the United Nations
column7:
On the heels of the drastic cut in the funds earmarked for development cooperation by the Italian Government with the adoption of the 2006 Financial Law, we learned last week that the Italian Foreign Minister was preparing to make a significant cut in Italy's voluntary contributions to the main United Nations agencies (UNDP, UNFPA, Unicef, UNHCR, UNRWA, FAO, etc.), which would bring Italy's total multilateral contributions down to less than the amount some European countries contributed to just one United Nations agency in 2005.


How does the Council view this measure?


Does the Council know of other EU Member State governments that have taken similar measures or intend to do so?

In the opinions of the GMO Scientific Panel for notification C/ES/01/01 for 1507 maize, notification C/F/96/05.10 for Bt11 maize and for the request from the Commission related to the safeguard clause invoked by Hungary according to Article 23 of Directive 2001/18/EC(1), it is stated that ‘maize ... is not a significant food source for endemic lepidoptera’.


On what studies do they base this assertion? The UK Natural History Museum's caterpillar hosts database is as comprehensive as currently possible, but contains records of known host plants for just 15 % of the world's described lepidoptera species. Even so, it lists 33 species from the European region known to feed on maize.


Why did EFSA not take this information into account?

n ‘A New Framework Strategy for Multilingualism’ (COM(2005)0596 final) the Commission committed itself in its conclusions to undertake the following actions:

— to set up a High Level Group on multilingualism, made up of independent experts, to assist it in analysing the progress made by Member States, and to provide support and advice in developing initiatives, as well as fresh impetus and ideas;

— to hold a ministerial conference on multilingualism to allow Member States to share the progress they have made so far, and to plan future work;

— on the basis of Member States’ reports and the advice of the High Level Group, to present a further communication to Parliament and the Council, proposing a comprehensive approach to multilingualism in the European Union.


What progress has been made in implementing these actions?


What guarantees and safeguards exist to ensure that the development and protection of minority and lesser-used languages such as Irish, Welsh, Scots-Gaelic, Basque, Catalan, etc. will be treated as essential aspects of multilingualism by the High Level Group?

The European Company Statute is a new legal instrument for undertakings, albeit one which has still to be perfected, and a political step forward for Europe.


Following the technical measures taken at national level, in France it has been possible, in practical terms, to form a European Company since June 2005. However, over a 12-month period not one application for the registration of a European Company was lodged on French territory.


A wide range of criticisms have been voiced, as regards both the substance of the Statute (lack of any specific tax provisions) and the administrative arrangements (excessive delays resulting from the institutions' slow working methods).


In the area of taxation, an immense amount of work has still to be done. No Member State must lose sight of the fact that a European Company can register in another State. For example, in fiscal terms it is much more attractive for an undertaking to register in Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands or Denmark than in France. France has a lot to lose in the light of its territorial tax system, something which is becoming the exception in Europe.


Article 69 of the regulation on the European Company Statute stipulated that, at the latest five years after its entry into force, the Commission would submit to Parliament a report on the application of the regulation and, if appropriate, proposed modifications.


Has the Commission grasped the extent of this failure? How does it explain it? In the light of this failure, does it plan to bring forward the submission of its report on the application of the regulation, with a view to presenting proposed modifications as soon as possible? What approach might offer a way out of the fiscal impasse which is the inevitable result of differing tax systems?

column5: Awarding of projects to consultancy firms
column7:
During the debate of 25 November 2005 in the Greek Parliament, the opposition denounced the fact that the Greek Finance Ministry (YPOIKO) had awarded projects financed from the EU Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund directly to consultancy firms. The projects concerned (technical consultancy studies or services) were awarded after the various economic topics had been divided up, using procedures which have been described as subterfuge (cursory competitions, for example). At the same time, it appears that the selection of the technical consultants for the 13 Greek regions is to be completed in 2006. This would make it pointless to recruit a large number of consultants whose work will no longer be relevant to the current programming period.


Which projects were awarded to consultancy firms by the Finance Ministry in 2004 and 2005, either directly or through cursory competitions? What are the names of the firms which were awarded projects, what prices were stipulated in the contracts and when exactly were the projects awarded? What was the justification for the Finance Ministry's use of fast-track procedures in each individual case? From which Community funds and operational programmes are these projects financed? When were they included in the programme, who is the final beneficiary and/or implementing body, and what is the total amount of appropriations assigned to this expenditure (for each final beneficiary) in 2005 and 2006? In what way is it expedient to continue with the procedure for recruiting technical consultants in the 13 regions when it has already been suspended for more than a year?

column5: Draft Act No 6229 of the Italian Chamber of Deputies
column7:
Draft Act No 6229, which was definitively adopted by the Italian Chamber of Deputies on 24 January 2006, lays down provisions governing the nursing, obstetrics, rehabilitation, medical technology and preventative healthcare professions and delegates to the Italian Government responsibility for instituting the relative professional associations. That Act sets itself the objective of ensuring that these associations are established.


This will lead to the setting-up, for example, of professional associations for biomedical laboratory technicians, physiotherapists, preventative health experts and speech therapists, etc.


This clearly conflicts with the principles of free movement, with Directive 2005/36/EC(1) on the recognition of professional qualifications and with the explicit calls made to Italy to abolish professional associations definitively.


Moreover, the Italian Senate has already adopted Draft Act No 6293, Article 1(f) of which places the profession of physiotherapist on a par with that of gymnastics teacher (graduate in motor science), thereby bracketing together two completely different professions.


In the light of the above, can the Commission indicate what action it will take to ensure that Italy abides by the rules in force?

column5: National Centre for European Information and Documentation — CIDE
column7:
By law of 23 June 2003 No 178, the Italian Government was authorised to sign an agreement with the European Commission to establish the National Centre for European Information and Documentation — CIDE. This body was set up, in the form of a European Economic Interest Grouping (EEIG), in March 2001 for the purpose of providing information, documentation, training and other services for Italian citizens relating to European Union policy issues, mainly through initiatives for the general public. By decision of 28 November 2005, the Commission announced that, on expiry of the current contract (April 2007), it would not be able to extend its direct involvement as a member of the EEIG in currently existing National Information Centres on the EU (including in France and Portugal) because this had become technically incompatible with the provisions of its new financial regulation. However, it plans to offer alternative forms of cooperation, based on ‘management partnerships’, which could continue to co-finance the activities and projects of a CIDE-type national centre.


At a time when all EU Member States are maintaining that they wish to step up efforts to bring citizens closer to the process of European integration and are acknowledging their duty to cooperate with the European institutions in improving communication on EU policy decisions in order to build up a genuine European public opinion, Italy seems to think that it can abandon the sole general institutional and operational instrument with specific powers and mechanisms that can serve this purpose.


Is the Commission prepared to review its decision?


Can the Commission explain what it means by the term ‘management partnerships’? How can it ensure that experience and professional skills that have been acquired are not lost?

column5: The Commission's views on cooperation between local authorities
column7:
At a workshop organised by the Council of European Municipalities and Regions (CCRE) on 29 September 2005, Mr Rein of the Internal Market DG said that public procurement law was applicable to all forms of written agreement between public authorities involving any kind of valuable consideration or quid pro quo.


It is therefore becoming increasingly unclear in what cases local authorities still have the right to entrust a task to an inter-authority organisation set up by themselves, as the Commission evidently takes the view that public procurement law must always be applied. An article published in ‘Lokaal’ — a publication of the Flemish Union of Local Authorities (VVSG) — in November 2005 concludes from this that the Commission virtually never regards cooperation between local authorities as an in-house award of a contract, because a number of local authorities are involved and therefore it is not possible to exercise control in the same way as in relation to their own departments. In taking this view, the Commission goes further than the Teckal judgment, which refers to similar control. The same article also states that the Commission has for some considerable time been investigating all forms of cooperation between local authorities, including autonomous municipal undertakings in Belgium.


The following questions therefore arise:

— What is the state of play in the investigation into cooperation between local authorities in Belgium?

— To what extent does the Commission still consider cooperation between local authorities to be possible without any violation of public procurement law?

— Why, in assessing such cooperation, does the Commission adopt an even more restrictive position than the Court of Justice?

The answer I received from Commissioner Kallas to my previous Written Question P-4955/05 is totally evasive, unforthcoming and incomplete.


With reference to the criteria adopted by the Board of Governors on 25-26 October 2005, I would like to know how these are interpreted by the Commission, which is part both of the Brussels IV follow-up group (Groupe de Suivi) established by the Secretary-General of the European Schools, and of the Board of Governors of the European Schools, which will have to decide in April 2005 what language sections will be sent to the Brussels IV school.


In view of this, I would again ask the Commission what its interpretation is of criterion C. In other words, does the Commission consider it possible to achieve a correct geographical balance of language sections in the four Brussels schools? How does the Commission propose to do this?


How does the Commission interpret criterion F? In other words, looking at the map of Brussels, the centre of the city and the locations of the four school sites, would the Commission indicate which of these sites, in its opinion, can be considered central and which peripheral?


Finally, with reference to the optimum number of students per section, can the Commission specify which Board of Governors sub-group (was it perhaps the Brussels IV follow-up group?) recommended a number in the range 300 to 700, when that recommendation was made, and on the basis of what criteria, given that the Board of Governors had previously taken as a guideline a threshold of 159 students per language section?

It was alleged in the Financial Times of London on 13 November 2006 by John Plender that since the publishing of the European Communities 2005 annual accounts under the new accruals basis a serious budget deficit has been uncovered which was previously disguised when the accounts were published on a cash basis.


He states that considering liabilities that are due but for which no invoice or cost claims have yet been made during the tenure of the previous President Prodi Commission, and removing a questionable asset raised to reflect member states' guarantee of the Commission staffs pensions, along with other smaller adjustments, a EUR 14.5 billion surplus of net assets as was previously reported now turns into a massive EUR 51.6 billion deficit.


Can the Commission confirm these figures and can it explain how it proposes to correct this deficit as the EU financial perspective has been already fixed for 2007-13?

column5: Plan D for Democracy, Dialogue and Debate
column7:
Will the Commission consider:


(a) that the Commission, in response E-2523/06EN, stated that Plan D has ‘fulfilled the commitment to represent the whole spectrum of views as stated in COM(2005)494 final’; and


(b) that the Commission in response E-4720/06EN identified the Europe Direct centres as a key part of Plan D; and


(c) that in the latest EuroBarometer survey on a single European currency (EB48.0), 39 % of citizens in Denmark said they were ‘very much against’ their national currency being replaced by a European currency.


Can the Commission confirm that the Europe Direct centres throughout Denmark will be representing the views of this more than one third of Danish citizens?


Can the Commission give some concrete examples of where literature and information contained within Europe Direct centres in Denmark represents the view that a European currency replacing the Kroner would be a bad thing?

In 2005, 131 judgments were passed against the 15 old Member States for infringements of Community legislation. Did that number increase in 2006? Is there any data concerning similar cases in the 10 new Member States which acceded in 2004?

In a letter to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) published by the Wall Street Journal recently (http://opinionjournal.com/editorial/011907letter.pdf), Ambassador Mark Wallace of the US Mission to the UN reveals that since 1998 the UNDP programme in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) ‘has been systematically perverted for the benefit of the Kim Jong Il regime’.


Ambassador Wallace details that:

— UNDP pays cash to local DPRK government suppliers, in violation of UNDP rules,

— UNDP funds DPRK-controlled projects without oversight,

— UNDP pays all local staff salaries directly to the DPRK government,

— all UNDP local expenditure and procurements are paid in cash directly to the DPRK government.


According to the UNDP's 2006 annual report, the European Commission provided USD 426.9 million to the UNDP in 2005.


How much money did the Commission provide for 2006, and how much has the Commission committed for 2007?


In light of this scandal, will the Commission suspend payments to the UNDP until the results of the inquiry ordered by the UN Secretary-General are known?


Will the Commission also suspend all payments, including co-financing and voluntary funding, to all UN activities in North Korea pending the outcome of the system-wide inquiry?

column5: Consultation of the public in the EU legislative process
column7:
We have been approached by a company which is seeking to obtain amendment to Regulation (EC) No 92/2005(1) implementing Regulation (EC) No 1774/2002.


Specifically, the current title of Annex III (p. 31) to the regulation in question is: ‘High pressure hydrolysis biogas process’. The company wishes to add to this title so that it would read as follows: ‘High pressure hydrolysis biogas process/high pressure high temperature hydrolysis process ATZ’.


How would this be possible in law? Clearly, the regulation would need to be amended. Which appropriate authorities can the company approach?

The brain drain from Europe and the immigration of foreign graduates, proportionately and globally lower than in Australia, Canada and the USA, is reducing Europe's research capabilities and weakening its innovation capacity. This problem needs to be looked at closely because 87 % of North Africans entering the EU have had no higher education. The fact that 900 highly skilled workers arrived in Germany in 2005 while some 22 000 German professionals left the country to look for work abroad in the first six months of 2006 should give us food for thought on the causes of this phenomenon. Meanwhile, the number of skilled workers emigrating to Australia has risen from 71 240 in 2003 to 97 000 in 2006. The ‘Green Card’ which the Commission is planning to introduce is, in our view, an appropriate means of simplifying bureaucratic procedures for the entry of highly skilled workers into the EU.


1. Does the Commission really believe that the brain drain from the EU and the lack of immigration of highly skilled personnel is due to bureaucratic complexities?


2. Does it not agree, instead, that it is more a result of the constraints and corporatist forms of protection and privileges preventing the recognition of merit and the corresponding remuneration?


3. Does the Commission agree that, in addition to a European ‘Green Card’ to combat bureaucratic complications, other measures should be taken to liberalise situations and remove the blocages in the way of labour market processes and the recognition of suitable remuneration levels?


4. Does it not consider it appropriate to reconsider the so-called ‘European social model’ (high unemployment and low wages) in order to be able to compete on the world market with those countries taking in an increasing number of highly skilled workers?

column5: Sale of the new Apple iPhone
column7:
Apple intends to market its iPhone in a number of European countries this year, for example in France, Germany and the United Kingdom. However, anybody who buys an iPhone is required to take out a subscription with a particular operator. In France it will be Orange, and in Germany T-Mobile.


In Belgium, there is strict legislation concerning commercial practices, which completely prohibits tied sales. In other European countries, the law on this subject is less strict, depending on how European Parliament and Council Directive 2005/29/EC(1) of 11 May 2005 on Unfair Commercial Practices is interpreted.


1. By concluding exclusivity contracts with an operator in each Member State, is Apple infringing Directive 2005/29/EC?


2. Will the Commission ask Apple to explain its actions? If so, when?


3. Does the Commission intend to revise Directive 2005/29/EC? In doing so, will the Commission adopt a stricter attitude towards all forms of tied selling?

column5: Public participation and access to justice and Ireland
column7:
Further to its answer of 6 June 2007 to my Question E-1859/07 concerning its challenge to the Irish authorities with regard to the directive on public participation and access to justice (2003/35/EC(1)) (Commission investigation 2005/0663), could the Commission elaborate on its statement that certain information communicated by the Irish authorities proved to be factually incorrect?


What information proved to be factually incorrect?

Council Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005(1) of 20 September 2005 established a single legal framework on support for rural development throughout the Community by the European Agricultural Fund For Rural Development (EAFRD).


In view of the fact that many Maltese and Gozitan farmers are weary of the ‘points system’ utilised in the evaluation process by the relevant Maltese Administration (for the period 2004-06), can the Commission ensure that the new system for the period 2007-13 is more comprehensive, user-friendly, foolproof, and readily available, thus ensuring that there will not be a repetition of having hundreds of farmers going through the expense of filing an application only to find out that they were not successful?

column5: Writing off of debts by the Commission
column7:
According to the Commission, debts totalling EUR 90.1 million were written off in the discharge procedure for 2005.


What amounts were written off in the years 2004 and 2006?


Will the Commission be publishing — under its transparency initiative — the names of companies and/or persons who have had debts written off?

1. Is the Commission aware of the ICE (In Case of Emergency) initiative of 2005, under which mobile telephone owners were encouraged to record telephone numbers (and addresses) of contacts whom the emergency services can call directly if the owner has been involved in an accident? This can save the emergency services from wasting valuable time trying to establish who they should contact if a person has been seriously injured and it is not possible to communicate with the victim.


2. Can the Commission indicate whether it supports this initiative and if so, what resources it can deploy for it?

Article A of the Treaty Establishing the European Union commits its signatories to a union ‘in which decisions are taken as closely as possible to the citizen’. Could the Commission explain how this Treaty obligation is compatible with the implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon without referendums, and in defiance of the rejection of its contents by the voters of France and the Netherlands in 2005?

Directive 2004/54/EC(1), on minimum safety requirements for tunnels in the Trans-European Road Network, was published in April 2004. It stipulates, inter alia, that states have responsibility for inspecting tunnels, as a result of Parliament and the Council having demanded the full application of the principle of subsidiarity and delegated to the national Authorities full responsibility for conducting inspections in the specific area of tunnel safety.


However, it has been announced on various occasions that the Commission will fund a ‘EuroTAP’ project, to be launched in January 2005, with the aim of carrying out practical monitoring of safety in road tunnels through safety tests on such tunnels in the Union whose findings will be made available to consumers and widely publicised.


The scheme as a whole is based on a system of assessment of the potential safety risk and service provided by tunnels, applied unilaterally by the project.


In the light of the aforementioned provisions of Directive 2004/54/EC, will the Commission answer the following questions:

— Why is funding being provided from the Community budget for an activity whose aims appear potentially harmful to the prerogatives of Member States and to interfere with specific competences conferred by Directive 2004/54/EC to inspection bodies, tunnel administrators, safety authorities, etc.?

— Secondly, what red line does the Commission intend to impose in order to ensure that ‘monitoring’ does not turn into ‘inspection’, and what criteria does it believe should be applied in the implementation of the project, aimed at informing consumers, with respect to the more general aims pursued by Directive 2004/54/EC, relating to traffic safety and, hence, to the protection of road users?
Does the Community acquis as regards equality of opportunity between men and women also apply inside the EU institutions? Are there specific derogations within the institutions?

Directive 2000/34/EC(1), which extends the 1993 Working Time Directive (Council Directive 93/104/EC(2)) to the excluded sectors, was scheduled to be transposed by all Member States by 1 August 2003 (for mobile transport workers) and by 1 August 2004 (for junior doctors).


The Irish Government has already admitted that it is not in compliance with this legislation, with particular regard to junior doctors. What steps has the Commission taken to ensure that the working hours of mobile transport workers and junior doctors comply with this legislation?

All European languages, regardless of how widely spoken they are, form part of Europe's rich cultural heritage which must be scrupulously respected and fostered. In this context, the Ebner report on regional and lesser-used European languages (2003/2057(INI)) made a number of valuable recommendations to the Commission with the aim of increasing the support given to such languages.


The resolution adopted by Parliament advocated, inter alia, that a new budget item be established in the course of the annual budgetary procedure with the corresponding appropriations to finance a multiannual programme for linguistic diversity, including ‘regional, minority and sign languages’, with a new legal basis. However, the Commission has made no provision for creating this new item in its preliminary draft budget for 2005.


Will the Commission shortly be proposing a new legal basis allowing substantial funds to be earmarked for promoting lesser-used languages?


The Ebner report likewise proposed the creation of a European Agency for Linguistic Diversity and Language Learning, which would also deal with ‘minority’ languages.


Will the Commission propose the creation of this agency in the near future, as called for by Parliament?

On 3 September 2004 the Commission adopted a communication, which among other issues dealt with the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) and measures that can be taken, to make SGP more effective. More specifically, Commissioner Joaquín Almunia announced that ‘the Commission intends to push forward this debate in an open and transparent manner and in close cooperation with Member States. Our proposals introduce more economic rationale in the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact while strengthening surveillance and enforcement.’ (Press release IP/04/1062).


On 14 December 2004 the Commission lifted all sanctions against France and Germany, the eurozone's two biggest economies, over breaches of the 3% budget deficit ceiling - despite fears that Germany at least will fail to comply next year for the fourth consecutive year. Specifically, RWI, one of Germany's six leading economic institutes, forecasted that the country's budget deficit would be 3.4% in 2005, as it cut its growth estimate from 1.5% to 1.3% and warned that the outcome could be even lower if the dollar continued its slide against the euro.


Is the decision taken by the Commission on 14 December a reflection of what Commissioner Almunia considers to be transparency and strengthening of the enforcement of the SGP?


How is the Commission prepared to react in a similar case (2-3 years not meeting SGP criteria) if a country with a considerably smaller economy than Germany or France is involved? Will that country have the same treatment as Germany and France or will a discriminatory policy be pursued against that country?

Under the principles of European governance providing for less direct administration by the Commission, more effective controls on results and a better cost-benefit ratio, a large number of decentralised agencies have been set up. There are 23 at present, and another five are proposed in the Commission's draft budget for 2005.


The increasing number of agencies (in 1990 there were only three) has led to much higher levels of expenditure, as normally entered under heading 3 of the financial perspective (internal policies) - rising from EUR 96 m in 2000 to an expected EUR 281 m in 2005.


This has a substantial impact on heading 3 and risks jeopardising the other policies and programmes under that heading.


It is therefore essential to ensure the highest possible levels of transparency and monitoring in respect of the agencies' expenditure. It is equally vital to operate a carefully planned personnel policy, taking account of the Staff Regulations and of the need to ensure a geographical balance of human resources and maximum effectiveness in achieving the objectives set.


In view of the above:

1. What is the Commission's evaluation of the situation?

2. What initiatives have been taken to ensure respect for transparency, planning and the effectiveness of action of the individual agencies?

3. What actions will the Commission take to ensure that the public and private sectors in the Union can derive maximum benefit from the work of the agencies?

column5: Funding for the referendum on the European Constitution
column7:
As regards the ratification of the European Constitution, what guarantees can the Council offer concerning the use of the sums earmarked in the 2005 budget?


What instructions or information will be given by the Member States to ensure that those calling for a ‘no’ vote are treated on a strictly equal footing with those in favour of voting ‘yes’?


If the principle of equality is not respected, what will the Council do to remedy the situation, subject to the possibility of appeals being brought before the competent courts?

column5: State aid measures for technology and business centres
column7:
According to information it has released, the European Commission intends to carry out a fundamental review of the approach to funding for technology and business centres, under the formal procedure pursuant to Article 88(2) of the EC Treaty. The administrative rules governing aid measures lay down a time-frame of up to 18 months for this process. As a result of staff and organisational changes within the Commission, the full period available is likely to be used, so that no new funding can be approved until autumn 2005. Given that this measure will undermine the national and international competitiveness of SMUs and regions with poor infrastructure, I should like to put the following questions to the European Commission:

1. What arguments had the European Commission put forward against the German rules and what stage has been reached in the procedure?

2. What long-term impact will the procedure have on national and European competition?

3. In the Commission’s view, to what extent will this measure hamper or even halt the development of fuel cells for the market?

The Independence Party claims that 95% of legislative measures proposed by the Commission are enacted without any amendments resulting from parliamentary scrutiny.


How many legislative measures of each category (directive, regulation, etc.) were introduced by the previous Commission between 1999 and 2004?


How many of these required the European Parliament's approval through the codecision procedure?


How many were rejected or withdrawn following opposition from (a) the Council or (b) Parliament?


How many are still under consideration by the Council or Parliament?


How many were enacted only after amendment by the Council?


How many of those adopted under the codecision procedure were enacted only after amendment by Parliament?


How many other measures, such as those over which Parliament has only the right to be consulted, were eventually enacted only after changes had been made that accommodated concerns expressed by Parliament?

Will the Commission confirm its interpretation of the insurance mediation directive (2002/92/EC(1) of 9 December 2002) as it affects independent financial advisers (IFAs) operating in the United Kingdom?


Will they be required to have professional indemnity insurance of at least EUR 1 million annually for each claim, and in aggregate EUR 2 million per year for all claims?


If so, will the Commission give the total number of IFAs in the UK, and also estimate the number likely to fall within the scope of the directive?


Will the Commission estimate the typical cost of such insurance for IFAs operating at each decile of turnover, and will it state its assessment of the impact of the measure on IFAs and on the market for personal financial advice in general?


Will the Commission confirm that at present in the UK, small IFAs are allowed to self-insure, thereby allowing small firms to continue trading?


Would such a waiver or a similar mechanism be available to the competent authority once the directive's provisions are implemented before 15 January 2005?

What response, if any, has the Commission received from the Irish Government as a reaction to the reasoned opinion issued to Ireland in July 2004 (as announced in IP/04/891) regarding Ireland's apparent failure to fully comply with the Directive on Public Lending Rights - Directive 1992/100/EE(1)1? Which establishments in Ireland does it believe should not be classified as ‘exempted institutions’ under this Directive?


Why has the Commission launched this challenge, given its comment that the ‘exclusive PLR is not infringed by the lending of items without any remuneration by educational establishments and establishments to which members of the public have access in Ireland’ (page 10, 12 September 2002 Commission report on the public lending right in the European Union - COM(2002) 502 final)?


Could the Commission provide an overview of the types of institutions that are not included in the list of exempted lending institutions by other Member States and outline the most recent conclusions that it has drawn regarding the impact of this Directive on lending institutions across the EU?

The Commission's Directorate-General for Taxation recently published on its web site the findings of a survey on company tax compliance costs. It showed that tax obligations account for extremely high costs, which increase with cross-border activities and may have an impact on a company's international operations.


According to the findings of the survey, costs relating to company tax are high, especially for small and medium-sized undertakings. The main problems mentioned by businesses include disparities in tax systems and a lack of information. Many businesses also consider that taxation has an impact on location decisions and investments.


In this context, will the Council give details of its thinking with regard to company tax? What is the current situation as regards harmonisation of the tax base or the introduction of a minimum tax rate - two measures which have often been mentioned but have never materialised?
